UI2AVKsixd-jmTTPHHOMlA.text: "Asakusa" is basically the closest place to a real Japanese tradional restaurant you could find in London. Period. I know what I'm saying because I spent a month in Japan and visited dozens of bars and restaurants. Forget the elegant and fashionable western-style Japanese restaurant: here you'll find the authentic japanese food, place and feeling. The menu is written both in Japanese and English (unfortunately it seems like most of the courses are only written in Japanese, though) and you will find almost every dish your mouth could taste in Tokyo or Kyoto. They have a large selection of sushi and sashimi but in my opinion the great value of Asakusa is that it shows that Japanese cuisine is not only raw fish and rice. On the contrary, everyone who spent some time in the land of the rising sun will tell you that sushi and sashimi rarely find their place on the everyday meal. You can then choose between udon, soba, yakitori, tempura and a lot of other delicacies you'll hardly find at this price. Obviously you can also choose between a large range of Japanese beers, traditional sake and shochu (Japanese wine) as well. There's also a set menu that will help them who are not very familiar with the Japanese cuisine. By choosing one of the sets (bento) you will discover the deliciousness and richness of Japanese food and spend a ridicolously small amount of money, sometimes even less than 10£! For the vegetarian customers who think Japanese food is only about fish: come here and discover how many wonderful dishes without meat or fish you can find. There's also a "yasai bento" (veggie menu) which is very cheap and will not leave you hungry. The only downside: it's always full booked, and for a reason. Call and book your table as soon as you can and, believe me, you won't be disappointed.

xRjJFaYDU3c7Jvzrhuap_Q.text: Maybe I'm going to be a bit critical since I was expecting so much, but I definitely was underwhelmed after my visit to Asakusa. I already knew that the interior and ambience was going to be lacking, but the tables are completely squished together, and it didn't help that the table next to mine had two women conversely in Mandarin loudly and burping. I digress, so now on to the food.I definitely think that the highlights on the menu here are the cooked dishes. I ordered the braised pork belly (it was a bit overcooked and very stringy- the dish is similar to a Vietnamese one I always make so it's possible to braise pork belly without making it so dry), the eggplant ( which was nice just maybe slathered with a tad bit of too much sauce), the fried oysters (delicious but not something to write home about), the spicy squid, prawn tempura, and the ika tempura (the batter on this batch was way too thick). I also ordered the agedashi tofu which was delicious, as was the soft-shell crab. I ordered the maguro, hamachi and sake sashimi. Hamachi and safe were delicious, but as usual the maguro was very stringy, although this seems to be a very frequent occurrence in the UK. No toro? I'm a bit disappointed- guess I'll go to Sake no hana for that. The rolls are definitely a waste of time and money.All in all, the prices are very reasonable, I felt like my boyfriend had to roll me home. We spent £73 in total (but that's without wine/ beer)- yes, we eat A LOT. Despite my food coma, I didn't feel completely satisfied and that I wanted/ expected a little something more. I would probably give Asakusa another try, but I wouldn't call it my new sushi bar home.

PTMnH6Az8fcsnw2RCdSWCw.text: This was our very first visit. Having voiced to mates and looking through the critiques we've been stop anticipating dining here. The service was extremely good. Very attentive. The climate was peaceful yet inviting.They're going the other distance ensuring their guests are content.This became the prettiest satellite dish That i've ever had!I suggest this restaurant if you love foodstuff. Very accomodating personnel, try to there when you really need them.

TUtRUyfYdt3WpoIZmlIIfg.text: Had a great time, food was excellent. Thanks guys

P5bVchMOP_qfDn_HavQs0g.text: at asakusa they are more concerned with the quality of the fish and  the preparation of the rice  which adds up to excellent sushi in a more traditional sense (i.e. not for the crazy roll lovers) i find the prices to be really reasonable for london. it is very busy but you can usually get in between 9 and 10pm if you're in need.  sit upstairs!

BXash5bFgi6S1fWjd0GObA.text: OH Asa Kusa. How glad I am to have met you. And so easilyjust at Mornington Crescent tube!I can get past the fact that you aren't ritzy/trendy/uber-cool in interior. I can also ignore the fact that if you seat me downstairs, you keep me away from the magic of the sushi bar and give me a somewhat musty toilet smell to compete with. And why don't these things matter? Because you serve me the best Japanese food in London, for the least amount of money, and the least pretention, yet with the most authenticity!Thinking of my meal there last week, I can't help but crave you again. DIVINE aubergine with miso paste for starter, along with miso and crab soup; a crunchy golden tempura kit with succulent prawns, mixed veg and plenty of dipping sauce (could be stronger in flavour) with sticky rice; eel in a very, very 'special sauce'; followed by a huge salmon and avocado tamaki and teeny tiny tuna rolls. OH, and the wasabi and pickles - you give me more than I need. After all of this, and washed down with two (yes, two) bottles of Sake, two of us pay a total of 55 quid with service.sigh

hRUY7C-f_bsAmJ1M71v9mw.text: This restaurant is simply perfect, not too pricy, and a tuna that literally melts in your mouth!!

mqRGlezJ6Cyf3_uXVqdAzQ.text: Hidden between Kebab shops in an impossibly small spot, Asakusa doesn't inspire confidence when you're standing outside. Step through the door, however, and you'll realise why this sushi restaurant is one of the worst kept secrets in North London.Always full, many of the customers are Japanese people who know their sushi. Friendly staff, warm sake just a nod away, and an atmosphere of welcoming authenticity. This is one of my favourite places in the whole city.

ZTbmlFk5g-6xGdfIhTSDlA.text: Asakusa is a traditional, authentic, family-run Japanese restaurant lying on the quiet side of Mornington Crescent station. Mind you, this concealment from the hordes of Camden-goers is largely immaterial, given the ageing, drab facade of the restaurant's exterior, and by the very fact that it is invariably busy, chock-full of Japanese, locals, and food-lovers in the know. Phone up to book and you'll be greeted with ??? (Asakusa resutoranto desu!), likely followed shortly by I'm afraid we already have a lot of bookings tonight, such is the demand for this little piece of Tokyo removed. Open only in the evening, six days a week (and closed for holidays  national and family) there is generally space for those able to arrive soon after opening (around 6pm), and of course you can book days in advance for certain availability. The restaurant consists of three small areas: The main dining area hosts the fortunate guests, and near the kitchen there is a sushi bar, behind which the sushi chef (sometimes assisted by an extra pair of hands) is worked non-stop in order to satisfy the throng's substantial appetite. The modest decor of warm colours and dark wood make for a cosy environment, the walls adorned with posters advertising Asahi lager, oriental bric-a-brac, and most prominently, menu items written exclusively in Japanese. Thankfully, those not appearing on the standard menu have recently been translated onto an extra sheet for the more adventurous (chicken gizzard skewers anyone?). Operations are managed from inside a curious brightly-lit 'hut' with quaint clay roof-tiling, adding charm to a simple layout. You may however find yourself situated downstairs, alongside an antiquated (and thankfully inactive) tape karaoke system. More canteen-like in appearance, oft cold and suspiciously damp, there you'll have to trust that the food will take your mind off the surroundings. And herein lies the draw  traditional, simple cuisine done extremely well. You won't find cutting-edge culinary flare, but choose wisely and you'll wonder if the world of oriental food really needs any more than that with which it is already endowed. Meat is prepared beautifully, sauces are bold and flavoursome, and dished are well portioned, allowing you to balance your meal with an array of sides (one good reason to make it a social visit). A standard set dish of beef teriyaki or chicken shogayaki and some sushi is a perfectly tasty way to fill your stomach, but why not try their buta kakuni (simmered belly-pork in a special sauce) with rice, nasu dengaku (deep-fried aubergine topped with a sweet miso paste), and tem zaru soba (assorted tempura with cold noodles and a dipping sauce)? If you're not sharing then you're answer will probably be Because I cannot leave without having some of their excellent sushi!, and few people would argue with that. If you fancy an interesting collective experience try ordering a hot-pot (say a sukiyaki or the Asakusa special) and huddle around the burner, though for this you may need to order in advance. Now comes the bit you really didn't expect. This food comes at prices that are more fitting of Misato than Mitsukoshi, and remember the green tea is free! The Japanese waitresses are always polite, if sometimes run off their feet, and at peak times you can expect to wait a while for sushi orders while the chef clears the backlog. Still, all things considered, is there any wonder?

3sukGaM2HH_UuRcvKMqEOQ.text: London seems to be awash with kaiten sushi... which is awful... brits in general don't seem to know what sushi should taste like, i'm sorry, but "M&S Sushi" is NOT Sushi.... ...But this place is a hidden gem!! Its my absolute favourite place to go in London. The sushi is fantastic, the prices are low, the staff are lovely!! The menu is large, plenty to chose from, non raw fish eating diners will have no problem.The decor is not fancy, this is a tiny hidey hole... a place to get great sushi without any of the schmaltzyness people seem to be so obsessed with nowadays. Try the amazing beancurd and aubergine starter (wow!) and don't forget to look up 'Jack Daniels" on the drinks menu for punny misspelling.Oh and try and get a table upstairs. Actually this is vital.

efJzEOPscNxFVxj0g7vfng.text: Good authentic japanese food at a great price but be warned about service. The waitress forgot we asked for the bill and it took 20 minutes. We were also told that sushi and sashimi orders would take an hour due to a backlog of 10 orders they had! I overheard the waitress telling the next table to call ahead next time which is the first time I've heard that. Despite this, the katsu and tempura were excellent. We also had the yakitori and fried tofu which were also very good.

n6SDFp8qHlmnVZLox0XCIQ.text: Very difficult to book a table, but when you manage to do it, you will understand why you have to wait so long. You should definitely give them a try!!

yYt-XPOmOgWxC_BZBukxuA.text: Having eaten here several times now, I hate to say it but the quality (at least when I've visited) has been really variable. The cooked dishes are delicious and highly recommended (especially the squid), the staff are friendly and helpful and the prices very reasonable. I'd recommend asking to sit at the sushi bar if there's space available as well. It's always tricky getting in without booking unless you visit after about 9.30/10pm, but that says a lot about how popular this place is. The first time I visited I absolutely loved it. Since then, however, my one (big) criticism has been the sushi - the last time I visited I ordered maki rolls and ended up with stale rice and nori that failed to keep the sushi together and led to it falling apart when picked up. The cucumber in my cucumber maki tasted off as well. Maybe it's just that I've visited fairly late once or twice and the chef is using up the last of the day's ingredients, but I'm of the opinion that if your rice, nori and main ingredients are off then it's better to inform the customer that you can't meet the order than it is to provide them with something verging on being inedible.

ty0mKs-sq3Z7ieKxxJPHiw.text: After reading the positive feedbacks we decided to visit this restaurant only to be placed in to a small unpleasant room. Since the food was what the over hype was about we decided to taste the overall quality of the ingredients that they were using and so we ordered several sashimi's and sushi's, the food was good and the quality of the ingredients did excel however I did feel that I've tasted far better for half the price at numerous Japanese restaurants throughout London area.The number reason to why I decided to write this review was due to their sheer rudeness in service, the staff seemed really fake and did not treat us like customers and so at the end of the meal we asked for the service charge to be removed only to be asked if they done anything wrong. We were then given a disapproved look as we walked out of the building.To sum it up, there are far better restaurants in London and especially with most of the reviews of the restaurant being from several years you have to question yourself to trust a review that has aged as much as this restaurant.I wont be visiting again.

vblWtqr1eEts7F_DVTS_uQ.text: I have read so many amazing reviews for this place, so naturally, I was keen to try it out, as amazing and reasonably priced sushi places are quite hard to come by in London.It gets packed, so you have to book quite far in advance (at least a couple of days) and unfortunately, although we had booked in advance, me and my friend got stuck right in the corner at the back of the restaurant next to the kitchen by the bar (which didn't have anyone working behind it).  It was a bit squashed to say the least, and we were forced to cram up even more when the waitress squeezed two people in next to us.By the time we got here I was pretty starving and had a hankering for sashimi.  However, when the waitress came over to take our order she informed me that if we ordered fish we would have to expect to wait around an hour.  Hmmm.  Now, I know you are busy, but as a Japanese restaurant that has a lot of fish on the menu, why is the wait so long?!  Anyway, that was really disappointing because I was hungry like the wolf and there was no way I was going to wait an hour to be fed (and eating a couple of gyozas would not keep me ticking over for an hour).So we ordered the chicken teriyaki and rice.  I was not impressed.  The portion was pretty small and the chicken was not very tasty.  I also had this niggling feeling that the chicken was a little undercooked.The waitress was super-sweet though, and gave us each a little eclair toffee with our bill (which was probably the culinary highlight of my meal).Anyway, we left and had a good laugh about the whole experience, until we got on the 31 bus and my friend started to feel sick and I started to feel spaced out.According to the other reviews I've read, I should have had a better dining experience, and I am just hoping that this is a one-off bad experience....but in any case, I still wont be rushing back....

TNowvkBpdcEUN19MYfxkzg.text: Don't judge a book by its cover " would be the best way to describe the place.The sushi is amazing.

fLG6IDBj-k8yUA0IoDqjXA.text: What can I say? I am a huge Japanese food lover, and when I can make it down to London I always make sure to try and stop by this lovely little restaunt. The staff are so warm and friendly, willing to help you if you are not sure what to order or want something specific. The food is authentic and tastes great, and what makes me even happy is that it is cheap on the wallet! My only complaint is the decor and location, the first time i saw it I did not think much of it. It looks very old and worn down from afar, and the inside is cramped and musty. However, the great atmosphere and mix of customers really bring this place alive!Great quality overall. I would reccomend to everyone.

EnOuWvSifULbtB4ShK3e4Q.text: I need to temper my 4/5 stars rating with an echo of something somebody else mentioned here.  There is a 1 hour wait for fish (sushi, sashimi, etc.).  But here's my experience:We arrived just around opening and there wasn't anybody else there.  Just the 3 of us.  We ordered a sashimi set, a sushi set, some tempura and some various maki.  The miso soup for the sets came out first, quickly followed by the maki.  We devoured the soup, but our companion who had ordered the maki rolls decided to wait until we received the rest of the food.  Which arrived...50 minutes later.We acknowledged that there was only one chef on duty at the time but given that we arrived without any body else in the house...it seems odd.  However, after we had ordered other people had started to come in.  They pretty much all got served before us.There's also a 12.5% gratuity automatically added to the bill.  We asked to talk to the hostess who graciously came over and discussed the situation with us.  Apparently, our server should have told us that it would be an hour wait for the fish (she didn't).  She also suggested that part of the problem was the sous-chef was dedicated to making wasabi (how that makes a difference if you're the first through the door, I don't know).  She accepted our concern that by the time we got our main course we were extremely hungry and waived the gratuity.All said, though, very pleasant service, nice atmosphere and *amazing* food at a reasonable price.  I hope to go back and not get kicked out.

8kXDpYO8IH_hmXNre9EjuQ.text: If you can get a table this is THE best Japanese place in London and beyond. A great experience everytime

tVAqzc6LqpmiCvEGCbn-rA.text: Within the worn facade of this unimposing row near Mornington Crescent lies a real treat for fans of Japanese food. The prices are fantastic, our party of four paid around £65 overall, including service, and ate and drank to our hearts content. The variety of food on offer is excellent, from full blown sashimi sets to individual yakitori portions. Even the sole vegetarian in our party was well catered for, with delicious roast aubergine and vegetable tempura, as well as her share in the free-for-all endamame beans. The remaining carnivores were treated to an array of ox-tongue, chicken wings, tuna, mackerel and scallop sashimi, and delicious skewers of chicken yakitori. The sashimi was exceptionally fresh, the tuna succulent and flavoursome, the best I've had in London. All this was washed down with Sapporo Ichiban lager, as well as green tea. The service was brilliant, despite a packed house of mainly japanese diners. The atmosphere too was great, the regulars obviously have worked up a rapport with the staff and good-natured banter added to the feeling that Asakusa is special. One caveat is that the place, as I've said, is popular. So it's well worth booking in advance, preferably a day or so before. Saying this, if you don't mind eating late, after 9pm, then there's a good chance you can just walk in.

dH3GawbaJgaENad314BVCA.text: Traditional Japanese bistro that is always full after 6.30pm despite only opening at 6pm. I have always had to book a day in advance and it gets very busy with a range of locals, expat Japanese and couples.There are a wide range of dishes and you can go for a set meal or buy lots of different dishes with beer if you are loking for a tapas-style taster menu with friends.Great selection of beer and sake is listed all over the walls and the food is consistently good. This is traditional Japanese cuisine - good value for money and good portion sizes raher than focus onn presentation like in some more expensive restaurants. The only negatives are that it is always very cramped and the decor is very dated. However, the enthusiastic staff who speak in Japanese more than make up for this and if anything it adds to the bistor atmosphere. This is a great place that is a little different but well worth the time of searching out if you would like to try traditional Japanese food. So far it is the only bistro style Japanese restaurant I have been able to find in London. Make sure to finish your meal with the green tea or chesnut ice cream!

zTKNJzwayGKv5ghpace0-g.text: This place really is an extraordinary find. I've never tasted Japanese cuisine outside of Kyoto that tastes quite like this. The sashimi is so freshand the suchi so light yet everything is well priced. They even take bookings although you have to do it quite far in advance these days. Personal favourites include the asparagus tempura which I dont think can be beat in any London restaurant. I cant stop eating it every time I go. I strongly recommend you try this place out if you can.

2utwzYpnydc9SrgbSaf_xQ.text: Asakusa is great! Yes, the decor is a bit shabby, but this is a genuine Izakaya experience with excellent food, and it's a great deal too. Go if you've got any experience of Japan and miss the food, because this is the closest thing you'll get in London.

J-mGUs4oTiSasCujrand0w.text: Without doubt the best Japanese restaurant in London. If you want to eat 'pretty' half-plate dishes go to Nobu. If you want conveyor belt sushi go to Yo Sushi. If you want fresh reasonably priced sushi, fantastic sashimi, beautifully soft and tender buta no kakuni (if you don't know what it is just ask for it. You won't regret it!) and a traditional wooden box of sake then Asakusa is the only place to go in London. Possibly the only downside to Asakusa is that it's so popular you have to book in advance, it's not always open on a Saturday (not uncommon with Japanese restaurants) and it's not as 'pretty' as Nobu or Matsuri. That said though, it's very authentic.

0vAO-Q9bSroYGJZWj4Cvgg.text: At this price level, in London, this is an outstanding Japanese restaurant. They are clearly not specialising in sushi, but even this was quite decent. I am incredibly picky about Japanese restaurants, but Asakusa will definitely be a place I will return to.

P674C5NblRTl4Td784C_Wg.text: Love coming here when I get the chance. Food is very good  love the sashimi but hate the fact that this place is fully booked every day!! Decors dated and service can be a little sloppy. Recommended but do book early!!!

20V-EKIVk4uDg069LMd-jg.text: I'd ideally like to give it a 3.5 star rating - but take into account I'm a bit picky about Japanese food and giving ratings (it's still above average!). I'm Japanese, and I can vouch for the authenticity of the food, and it's good, real Japanese food. This place gets filled really fast which proves it's good food- but I felt the wait staff was not very friendly and the service was below my expectations, which is why I decked one star. The other 0.5 star is because I felt it was a bit overpriced for the stuff that's on the menu. I know London has high standards of living - but for knowing that I could make almost everything that was on the home-cooked traditional food on the menu- it felt a bit ridiculous to be shelling pound after pound for something that simple.That said , their traditional home food was really good - and I would recommend it to anyone.  I'm sure their sushi is good too- but I heard Asakusa is good for their home traditional food, which is why I ate mostly that.

lIrX8JPiu5B18br8bWkdDQ.text: Maybe I'm going to be a bit critical since I was expecting so much, but I definitely was underwhelmed after my visit to Asakusa. I already knew that the interior and ambience was going to be lacking, but the tables are completely squished together, and it didn't help that the table next to mine had two women conversely in Mandarin loudly and burping. I digress, so now on to the food.I definitely think that the highlights on the menu here are the cooked dishes. I ordered the braised pork belly (it was a bit overcooked and very stringy- the dish is similar to a Vietnamese one I always make so it's possible to braise pork belly without making it so dry), the eggplant ( which was nice just maybe slathered with a tad bit of too much sauce), the fried oysters (delicious but not something to write home about), the spicy squid, prawn tempura, and the ika tempura (the batter on this batch was way too thick). I also ordered the agedashi tofu which was delicious, as was the soft-shell crab. I ordered the maguro, hamachi and sake sashimi. Hamachi and safe were delicious, but as usual the maguro was very stringy, although this seems to be a very frequent occurrence in the UK. No toro? I'm a bit disappointed- guess I'll go to Sake no hana for that. The rolls are definitely a waste of time and money. All in all, the prices are very reasonable, I felt like my boyfriend had to roll me home. We spent £73 in total (but that's without wine/ beer)- yes, we eat A LOT. Despite my food coma, I didn't feel completely satisfied and that I wanted/ expected a little something more. I would probably give Asakusa another try, but I wouldn't call it my new sushi bar home.

AYZ5N5YcI8vHbLyaJUkyrQ.text: This izakaya-style restaurant has been a regular haunt of mine since 2001.  Their pork belly is to die for, and while the sushi combinations take a while to bring out, they're delicious.The mama-san who runs this place is always brilliant.  I hope she's still there!

RvpVt3fNtLbE8jXUCOJhgg.text: Some of the best mouth-watering sushi I've had in London. Real Japanese ambience, especially upstairs. All Japanese staff.

yXMlb3eynqP2H_rK3nJKEQ.text: It was a couple of weeks ago and I remember it was quite good but I will have to go again to refresh my memory. I ordered a chirashi bowl and it was pretty well done.

C-zxeOYjrbgZwgOeA6HkXw.text: DELISH^a millionThank god for my metabolism cuz those sushi orders kept coming, and so did the chicken katsu and cold soba.  EVERYTHING was fresh and amazing, although the rice consistency was slightly too mush.  Hamachi, unagi, and spicy tuna nigiri were perfection (where is the toro in this joint though, seriously?).  Skip the rolls, they are whatevs...but do opt for some serious gyoza that did NOT look like they were from a frozen pack of Asian supermarket fame.If you don't mind stuffing your body into the sushi bar, feel free to stroll in RIGHT at opening time (6pm) without a reservation.  After that you're screwed.  Thank you for some legit Japanese Asakusaaaaaaaa!!!!  (tear)

809kxWWGpfOCNayqQlO0VA.text: This is a place you need to reserve for.  We were lucky that on a Tuesday eve at 6:30 we were able to get a seat at the counter.  Usually in a sushi joint, the counter is the coveted seat--but in this case it is a bit cramped and you do get some of the backdrop of the actual kitchen which is the site of dishwashing.  It was also a warm night, so it was a bit stuffy.The menu is massive--overwhelming in its options....we just went for the sushi and sashimi platters, although there were a lot of strange fishes that came on it, so next time I would definitely order ala carte.The udon wasn't a soup, and that was a bit perplexing.The spinach dish and the eggplant we ordered was divine.I loved the autenticity of Japanese food, and I would definitely go back the next time I have a sushi craving.

a8vvosYZdxMgbUnBLAYryA.text: You know its authentic and guaranteed to be tasty when the tables are filled with Asians (Orientals)! We just managed to get a table on a Saturday before the restaurant closed its kitchen for the night (around 10pm) so were grateful that they let us in at all! We were heading for Koko but thought we should first line our stomachs with some food and randomly stumbled upon Asakusa (literally across the road from Koko) - which I thought was the least likely place I'd put a Japanese restaurant in, but hey, I'm grateful for it as I work in Camden Town!Anyway, I'd imagine reservations is a must if you plan on eating dinner at normal hours.The restaurant is split over two floors - the ground and a basement floor. Its pretty cramped but in true Asian style, they've taken advantage of ALL available space. That said, the food here is something else! Since coming to London from Sydney (where Jap food is of such a high quality you almost don't feel the need to go to Japan), I've not be much impressed with the quality I've tried to date. Asakusa totally restored my faith in finding good Jap food in London! Can't remember everything we ordered but did recall their cold soba being amazing, unagi and softshell crab nigiris were divine and the yakitori was decent too. We didn't really get a chance to order much as they were closing in an hour anyway, but I'm certainly planning on coming back here time and again until I've made my way through their generous menu!

eH9MVG0kGAhHk8tHtuG92g.text: always on the lookout for japanese food, my friend and i came here before seeing my morning jacket at the roundhouse.  i had been wanting to try this place, but i don't come out to camden that much.like everyone says, make a booking, b/c the place is tiny.  on a monday night, it wasn't as difficult, and i was able to get a table by calling w/in a couple hours of showing up.food here is authentic and great.  there are lots of izakaya-type dishes, and the nasu dengaku, grilled sardines, and sauteed mushrooms were great.  then we got the sashimi platter and a chirashi to share.  both were delicious and the fish was really fresh, but the assortment wasn't that exotic.  we asked the server if we were able to get the chef's choice of sashimi, but she said we couldn't, so we got the standard tuna, salmon, sea bream, mackerel.  still good tho.  we finished off w/ some tea, and when our check came, so did 2 cadbury eclairs.  yum!i would give it 5 stars if only they did an omakase for fish!

jawUBgZK1lxSKyf8eGhhdA.text: Asakusa has never let me down. Whether you're going there for a group meal or for a more intimate dinner, the food is brilliant, there's always a buzz and the service is great.My absolute favourite is Nasu Dengaku which is fried aubergine and soya paste. Totally yum. In fact, I can't think of a dish I don't like. Whether you're in for the more safer dishes such as teriyaki or tempura or whether you're more adventurous with your food, all of it is presented decently and tastes great. Did I mention the value? All dishes are reasonably priced which means you can leave feeling stuffed and without an anorexic wallet. It's about 10 minutes walk from Camden Tube, and less than a minute (if you walk as fast as I do when I'm anticipating food...) from Mornington Crescent. I'd advise to book if you've got a large group. Unfortunately, they don't open at lunch else I'd be there everyday.

K_6toWW8_JV8fxNDgdqBxQ.text: Well, it's pretty much all been said but from now on anyone who visits me in London is definitely coming to Asakusa for Japanese food, whether they like it or not! How could they not though - the food's fantastic and super-fresh, the service is great and the decor and atmosphere is nice and down-to-earth. I'll be back soon! c*

k1SKpSeGiy-wWFuDgO3P2A.text: I was very impressed by what I had last night. I have been dying to try Asa Kusa for a while now especially as many a sushi snob I know have always spoken about this place in hushed tones. I've heard everything from "this is a secret place near camden" to "It has the best sushi in London but I'm not teling you where". Needless to say these are people I no longer consider to be friends. That aside I can see why they wanted to guard the place slightly. OK visually its very basic and the decor isn't super plush but that is something I liked about the place. I like it when a place is all about the food and last night it was definitely having a good night in terms of food. I had a sushi set and a beer. Very simple dinner but everything was lovely. The fish was of excellent quality and was cut so well it melted on the tongue. The Wasabi was especially firey too which was great for clearing my nose! My denim doppleganger had the same as me and we were both very happy. The sushi set came with types of nigiri and 2 maki rolls and a serving of miso soup. Was nice and light and just the right amount of food given that I am on a diet at the moment. I found the prices there very reasonable and I definitely want to go back to explore the menu further.

x8Fa3P-VTj-Wa2G9og_Sug.text: Went to Asakusa about a week ago and the thing that impressed me the most was the delicious sushi I had. Honestly I didn't really expect such quality dishes judging from the unpretentious looks of this place and the relatively low prices. As I said I disliked the decor but in the end it's the food that matters the most and when it comes to that Asakusa is definitely in my top 5 japanese restaurants in London.

kH2pRpe27BAXJjEfzicKGg.text: Asakusa is a small traditional Japanese restaurant just by Mornington Crescent tube station. I've tried coming here before only to be told that they are fully booked for the whole evening. This time I made a reservation and saw others being turned away. Remember to book a table, it's absolutely necessary. First off I should probably say that if you're into sushi (made by a proper chef, not the high street chain kind) then you definitely need to go here. This could very well be one of the best places for sushi in London, especially considering the price. The fish is really fresh and just melts in your mouth, served with just enough wasabi on still warm sushi rice. Would be a shame if it ended there but actually the hot dishes are just as good as the sushi. The takoyaki and Wafu beef were highlights (couldn't try all dishes even though I wanted to, I'm sure there are a lot more highlights on the menu). The squid with Ginger sauce was good as well, nice to have good quality and well cooked squid for once an not the chewing gum consistency kind, but was overshadowed by the other dishes. Desserts were good as well, I tried the black sesame and green tea ice creams, both of which were nice. I find it a bit hard though being excited about the dessert compared to the starters, main and sushi. Will have to go back soon to try the oter dishes.

pYsW4NJDXb4imxL4cow11g.text: The only worse thing about this place is that it's so far away from home, I wish I lived nearby. I swear that's the best Japanese restaurant I've ever been to. If you are a sushi lover just like me you should at least pay a visit.

tQVVQLmEdB4TDeKbEiHOQg.text: Over the years I have heard many rave reviews about Asakusa, the almost legendary Japanese restaurant in the unlikely setting of Mornington Crescent.I finally managed to get a reservation (you read that right) and headed down on a tuesday evening. Surprisingly for a midweek outing the restaurant was packed and I was glad to see some Japanese businessmen sitting merrily in the restaurant. It may sound like a cliche but to their decision to dine here reassured me.The menu is extensive including several specialities plus the obligatory sushi menu and best of all the food is very well priced. I made sure i picked my favorite speciality una-don (eel over a bed of rice) and was extremely impressed. The sushi was fresh as where the other ingredients making for a fantastic culinary treat. We even ordered a few "surprises" like stuffed aubergines which proved deliciousAsakusa's slightly dated decor adds character and authenticity to the small restaurant and the staff were extremely friendly. Sadly the restaurant loses a few points because the service was particularly sluggish. Though I had been warned this would be the case some sort of drink and/or snack to placate our hunger at the start would have been appreciated.Having said that, considering the price and  freshness of the food I will definitely be back

DelNhcRrphG8BIDfAiBY7g.text: Went for my fathers birthday as he is a big Japanese cuisine. I was sceptical because people wrote that this was the 'best japanese in london', but it was very good. The staff are friendly and helpful. It has an almost family run feeling, unpretentious and very nice atmosphere. The food is good, the sushi particularly so (the tuna really stood out, just melts in the mouth). The sake taster set is definetely worth a try. This place is busy, even on a week night it was pretty packed. So if you dont want to be dissapointed book ahead. All in all I thoroughly reccomend going.

6QVf8g-1tO1ttmzbhljodA.text: After having been to Asakusa once more the food was delicious again and the service was speedy so I needed to update Asakusa to the 5 stars it deserves!!

h2uNwz82WxCgUwDMFLPhPw.text: Unassuming - uninviting, even - from the outside, Asa Kusa charms immediately once foot is set across its doorway. Robust, assertive welcome from an almost-pushy, matriarchal waitress, decaying decor and lots of Japanese clientele give the place a proper olde worlde feel. The waiting staff are terribly friendly and quite delightful. The place serves Asahi Black - quite a rare find, it's lovely. The sushi is fresh and authentic; the tempura crisp and light; superb soba with beancurd and really good sashimi. I've been here many times and it never disappoints. Booking in advance is essential, especially at weekends as it gets very busy.

62RTN9X-AwPAlOxaawiYjg.text: Very very good Sushi, sashimi and other Japanese food. Wide range of Sake. Full of Japanese people. The interior is... interesting - it looks as though the current owners took over a 70s vintage greek or italian restaurant, complete with half-timbering and a little hut with a tiled roof. But the food is superb. About 2 minutes walk around the corner from Mornington Crescent tube station.This place gets booked up a week or so in advance for weekends, so you'll probably not be able to drop in unless you're alone.

KsnNgQ6xB1kDeOaV5R7FMw.text: As a new lover of sushi here in London, I've been trying to give the smaller, more traditional style spots a shot, and Asakusa performed how I expected it to.  This is traditional sushi, with many more cooked dishes than at a more Westernized spot (nonetheless very different from the high end Nobu, Zuma, etc..) and the fish quality was OK.  The price range is definitely very reasonable, but that being said, the fish is not top quality.  I tried the Asakusa Salad which was interesting in concept -- a raw fish salad with "special" dressing -- but there was just far, far too much dressing.  I would recommend this dish if the dressing comes on the side.  The salmon avocado inside out rolls were standard and yummy, and the spicy tuna tamaki hand roll was very spicy and good, I could have had another one!  I usually don't order cooked fish at sushi places, but the salmon tariaki dish was very good, as was the gyoza.They also have a large range of saki, with a taster menu including a description of each of the three, which was fun to try.I recommend this place if you're looking for a cheaper yet tradition sushi spot, but within this vibe and category, I think Kikuchi and Ikeda take the top slots.

IHnrqelkcFmkxcjWSZRd5Q.text: You must make a reservation. While the service was nice, the food took forever to come out. Make sure you order everything at once, otherwise you will be there over one and a half hours. The food was delicious, particularly the pork belly, eggplant, and the sashimi, but did not fill us up at all. We were still hungry at the end of the meal, and that's with us purchasing 6-7 small dishes costing around 70 pounds.Bottom line: While it was a nice dinner, we don't see ourselves really going again.

_6P6BUfBT3xxphC-K3LpkQ.text: It is my favorite sushi place on the city. The sushi is very fresh, a little tiny bit warm and very smooth. The avocado/salmon was my favorite out of all. Otherwise the pork belly and avocado was amazing as well. The service is fine, it only takes a little to make the sushi since only one person is making it (but very good!!)

V05DWOCZK8ysi7rG-O8i8A.text: We went here on our last night in London. The sushi was very fresh and the service was good. We were seated pretty quickly and I was surprised at how soon our food was served. The owners kept checking in on us very often. The place is super small so I can see it getting crowded from time to time. I spent a significant amount of my childhood in Tokyo and while this place does not feel like Japanese sushi joints, it does serve just as much fresh fish! We ordered the gyoza which was delicious. We ordered three roles between the three of two of us but I cannot for the life of me remember which ones they were. I wish we had ordered some noodles or soup because the folks next to us did and it looked AMAZING! I absolutely was drooling over their meal while waiting for mine. Compared to the rest of the places in London, this was not a bad deal. I believe we spent about 40 pounds on the whole meal, which was not bad for such a popular spot. Overall, would totally recommend this place if you are craving some Asian food in the midst of all the shepherd pies, donuts and steaks!

HJSXtHvQNOciSFVEs3eb7g.text: Another discovery courtesy of Yelp! Thank you, thank you, thank you.The authentic food and ambiance which definitely reminded me of my experience in Japan. Food-wise we had the miso soup, battered Quail egg on a stick, beef teriyaki, assorted tempura (vegetable, salmon and shrimp), sashimi squid and the assorted nigiri sushi that deliciously filled our hungry bellies. Although, the sushi did not tasted super fresh we still enjoyed the goodness of it. My other half definitely enjoyed the well marinated sashimi squid while I grubbed on the very tasty teriyaki. I must say that the menu here is pretty inundating as it seem to keep going on and on, hence the amount of food we ordered. Overall, wonderful find in London.

MKEQgduy-hl40hRrMiJB2g.text: Get there early - we made the mistake of getting there around 7 and had to wait about 2 hours... so of course had too many drinks at the pub nearby.  I will need to go back and try the food properly but from what I remember in between the haze of a magnum size sake bottle is that the takoyaki was amazing and we ordered a 2nd round.

c88AnwhjU5kJgDrGJeiLbg.text: If you read my reviews, a lot of them are about using the Yelp app on the go without planning and dropping by one of the recommendations. I warn you that its not a good method cause it backfires sometimes :) Thats a problem when you're with a hangry wife!!Hangry = Hungry + Angry.BUT when it works and you end up at a cool hole in the wall, authentic, Japanese restaurant its a lot of fun. And its exactly why i love Yelp!We loved everything, I say everything because I have to admit Japanese is not my strongest cuisine! I usually ask my wife to order and so far that has worked for me :)Because its a review I should try at least to find the things we ordered on the menu for you. OK I tried and failed! but here's what I remember :) We ordered an assortment of sushi which I know contained eel which I loved. We also had the vegetables dumplings, and the tampora mix.

tBUoM62GsFIdCgxKvm0dLQ.text: Typical izakaya with nice udon and sushi. The salmon sushi looks crystal and extremely fresh.

EV4SE0lVX3J7UlDB3N6WMw.text: My brother has been a regular here since some time in the 90s - and is still greeted with an enthusiastic "________-san!" on entry. Not the slickest or the most expensive Japanese restaurant in London, but if you can see past the well-documented eccentricities, it's a little gem.

oR-4js2F5meBkIizFgmyDA.text: Best Japanese in London. Unless you are lucky, you may have to reserve few days in advance (even weeks). It is properly Japanese, you might need some help to read the menu :) but the quality is really high. You can also guess it by the amount of Japanese people dining at the place.

u7AabgOnF89aJ88V6K_ElA.text: Definitely one of the best sushi places in London.**Note: Also great for hot Japanese food -- useful to eat at with friends who don't like sushi .Have been eating here for the past 5 -  6 years and went back last week (for the first time in a year) and was not disappointed. Don't let the shabby exterior fool you, this place is the real thing.So what if you can't read the food offerings in Japanese on the walls, there is plenty on this very varied menu to choose from. So what if the sushi takes ages to arrive and the food your table has ordered comes out at all different times....it makes it feel more like a family run place. Sit back and enjoy. They have an excellent sake selection as well.Tips:1. Make a reservation. It gets crowded quite quickly, even on what you might think would be a 'quiet night'.2. Order sushi early...if you are eating/order after 18.30 you will have to wait 30 minutes or more for your sushi.  If you are pressed for time get one of the hot dishes. My favorite is the salmon with soy glaze --  the portion is huge.Now pick up a big ol' piece of pickled ginger and dig in.

FuuZA5Wrxf9BEoezt_xF3A.text: Great little Japanese restaurant, with an amazing sushi chef. Perfect for a date, dinner with friends or a larger party. The have wonderful sake tasting menus for less than £10 for three glasses of different sakes. Highly recommended

ZBXGJzXQ4Pv-bEuo1dmiYw.text: Really horrendous service. We had a reservation and were seated at the table, but no one ever came by to take our order, not even drinks. After waiting 30 minutes we finally flagged someone down just to find that it would be an additional hour wait for sushi. No thank you.

6xHXBOq9dkaAq5zbKWzGcw.text: You know you are in a good place when the menu on the walls is only in Japanese. Bookings are a must as they get quite busy! Super fresh fish and a ton of other cooked options as well. Only gripe....the pork katsu meat was a bit dry and chewy.

XUpXrVLnhY-D1nVZXYW1Aw.text: I've been waiting to try Asakusa for so long - having had several failed attempts in the past. This time, my fiancee booked well in advance, and we found ourselves with a table there on a Saturday night! Inside, it definitely looks like you could have stepped in a local Japanese noodlehouse. There's menus in Japanese on the walls, and the place is humbly furnished. The food is definitely the highlight. Its not fine dining, nor is it extremely cheap, but the quality and authenticity of the food makes it so that its probably one of the best without having to pay fine dining prices. For £40, the two of us managed to get an extremely filling meal! Definitely recommended is the sashimi, which is extremely fresh and well prepared. The quail's egg and the gyozas were pretty good too, although the takoyaki balls were a bit disappointing. A highlight was the Asakusa Udon, which had a surprising mochi rice cake in it!!! Reviewed by The London Insiderlondon-insider.co.uk/201…

8GF_kMWC3aqQUpyQ7zD91Q.text: I was very disappointed by my nosy recent experience here. The food was absolutely delicious again, no problem there, but the service was not good at all. We were put in the basement which smells like toilets and we asked to get a table upstairs instead. We waited an extra half hour so we could sit upstairs. When we finally were sat down, the server took our order and gave us half of what we asked for. We waited 45 mins for enough sushi for 3 people and there were 4 of us. We left having enjoyed the sushi but still feeling hungry because it was too late to order more. I don't think the bad service was intentional, but I think something was lost in translation. I would still return here because the quality of the sushi really is delicious but I'm less enthusiastic than before.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Sake taster set - 'mirror of truth' on the left was my favourite.  Yum!

085xLcSrt-1gp_xYgJCLCA.text: I almost don't even want to write a review of this place -- it's crowded enough just on word of mouth.  But if you're looking for sushi in London, this is the place.  Yes, it looks like a Japanese restaurant took over a crappy Italian restaurant and didn't bother to update it.  Yeah, the specials are all in Japanese and are posted on plain pieces of paper taped to the wall.  Sushi takes forever to come out and sometimes the service can be abrupt when overrun.  I suppose these things would piss me off if the food wasn't so damn good.  And when I say good, I mean this-place-could-make-Nobu-its-bitch good.  This is one for your little black book to impress people with just how "in the know" you are.

i-TjTbECSYpquG86FZqHQg.text: There is a reason it is so hard to get a table here. Recently when I was in London however I managed to get sorted. My Girlfriend loves Sushi, and we just discovered she was pregnant. So before she had to embark on a massive 8 months without Sushi we booked our spot and had the best Sushi EVER!!!!!Amazing

UG-GlW-N0CFX5NTuRoUVGA.text: For affordable, honest Japanese food with an izakaya atmosphere this is the best you're gonna get in London. 1 star taken off because the flavours weren't quite there for me.

ckutcxjSAFQvdtKONKqE8A.text: This is my favourite Japanese restaurant in London. The food is delicious and super authentic. The gyoza, fried aubergine, miso soup, korroke & hamburg there is something i could eat every day of my life! Accompanied by a glass of plum wine!Really reasonably priced also.You have to book as it is always packed out!

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom

hyxn6Y7WEUP-PB-XiTOEtw.text: I had the weirdest experience here. Took my boyfriend here after work bc all the reviews were so glowing. We had a 9:30 reservation, and got there at 9:25. we were seated immediately, but when we started to order sushi the waitress sort of laughed and said something along the lines of, "it's going to be an hour for sushi are you sure you don't want to order something different. Tempura maybe?" Well we had gone there for the sushi so we decided to drink sake and snack on edamame while we waited for the food. An hour and a half later we got our food... it was good but definitely weird how long we had to wait. would not go back for that reason.

yHaHydopeNFTKjk8dt5hVQ.text: This place is awesome. Walked in and felt like I was in another country, Japan. The layout, presentation, staff and most of the customers here are Japanese. Talk about authentic, this place is a gem. Just got out of a concert and needed food badly, found out this place opens late. Walked in at 10.40pm and they still took orders. Has a wide selection of sushi, sashimi and set meals. Meal sizes are just nice and the prices are decent. High quality meat, tastes lovely  Lovely staff, quick service and lovely ambience. It's a nice place to chill, and have drinks. Enough seats for couples, groups and families. I wouldn't say it's kids friendly cause it feels like a place where adults come in to let go some steam after a long day (maybe it's because I'm here at almost 11pm). Also no space to park a stroller. I'm going to come back here to chill DF out lol

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. I asked for medium rare, I got medium rare. That's what I'm talking about.
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Sashimi Set 15
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Beef Shogayaki Set, comes with rice and miso soup 8

CCWZaehohR1xuiIA0rDb9w.text: The original Japanese owner of Asakusa retired in August, and it is now run by a new non-Japanese owner.  The quality went downhill, unfortunately.  Our starter arrived after we had finished our mains, and Tonkatsu was very tough.  Takosu was way too salty.  They still have polite Japanese servers, but the food was not good enough.  It used to be packed every night and there were full of Japanese diners.  We saw empty tables and no other Japanese tonight.I have been going there regularly for over 28 years and am very sad to lose a reliable local Japanese restaurant that served reasonably-priced authentic food.  I hope it will improve.

RIVFlAfj_kjRxJsVei9g5w.text: Got recommended this place for some authentic Japanese cuisine, have yet to find any in London so was super excited. We were a table of 3 mixed Japanese/Western. The place is only small, lucky we made a booking (which kind of sealed the deal for us because the guy was speaking Japanese ). The service is nice and friendly, food was great. The menu is extensive.... We ordered so much it was crazy. Beef tataki was the highlight along with the agedashi tofu . The tempura seafood was also ace. We did order yakitori and tsukune too but unanimously weren't keen on the *special sauce - bit on the salty side. Back there again this week so will check out other things on the menu

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Yakitori and Tsukune with special sauce. Not a fan of the special sauce
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. This seafood tempura was lovely
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Must order. Delicious.

Zl34s1JafE5KRa6sdHquoA.text: Inexpensive, authentic and good tasting Japanese food. You'll find this restaurant just around the corner from Mornington Crescent. You'll need to make a reservation here as it gets packed full of locals and Japanese people, for good reason. This place is a little hidden gem in London, as the restaurant really transports you to Japan, it is small, quirky, and best of all, Japanese Music is playing!They have lots of small dishes to offer, so I had Fried Oysters, Pork Belly, Mixed Sashimi, Takoyaki, Fried Aubergine, Tonkatsu, and finally some sweet Green Tea and Sesame Ice Cream. All dishes were good. I paid under £55 for all of this, including 2 glasses of wine and soft drinks. The service is really good, the staff are very friendly.But I have to add.. This isn't the best tasting Japanese food in London, none of the dishes wowed me, that's why I haven't given 5 stars. It is worthy of a visit though, as the food is so cheap and the experience and atmosphere are on-point. Thanks Asakusa!

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Asakusa Food

fGPv_WObdSRVH2TvLkWNwg.text: Ok so where do I start..... Let'sStart by saying that the place looks like a right hole from the outside. On walking in I was like "Ohh ok this ain't to bad" but then I realised there was nowhere to sit so they took us down stairs to where the over flow of customers go. Anyway first impressions of the downstairs was a bad smell, like a mixture of damp and cats piss... Also very old fashion decor and just dusty looking crap all over the place, it looked like it had not been painted or touched in over 30 years. The smell was really putting me off, I remember saying to my girlfriend that if the sitting Area ain't clean and it's stinky what's the kitchen like . Anyway long story short... The food was real good and the service just as good. But don't think I would go back as there is just as good "imo" Japanese restaurants "that don't smell like cats piss or look like they're from the 70s" near by. Bottom line is this place is always packed so it must be good, but me personally don't like a Stale stench while eating. Would have got a 4 if not for the smell and dirty looking decor.  But as I said the food was great.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Still Had a good time, I was very underwhelmed until I started eating the food. Nom nom.

LPrX1bG8bgU6dIBni0fAcw.text: If you're thinking of trying this restaurant. Just NO. Terrible service. Food is relatively fine but definitely not worth the hassle you have to put up with to get it. We were surrounded by incredibly rowdy customers who were shouting and screaming in a basement of a dirty and outdated restaurant with terrible decor. The toilet was filthy and there was only one for a man and a woman. So be prepared to queue.When we went to order after spending half an hour trying to get the attention of our waitress she informed us that the sushi would take an hour so being a little crushed as that's why we came here we chose other foods. It took an hour and a half for the food we did order. So basically we should have gotten the sushi as it would have been faster. What we got was a small portion of what could be described as chicken I guess and a small portion of pork. Took another hour almost to get one portion of ice cream and a bill. Never again.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Some dumplings we got. Definitely not worth the wait.

Wv0awDiByhQ0In72GlrYyg.text: I got the hamburg steak with salad appetizer, and then the sashimi set, which came with a bowl of rice and a miso soup.Both tasted good. The hamburg steak was a bit on the dry side, and I've had better sake sashimi at Eat Tokyo for a lower price.What was unbearable was the service. It took a solid 30 minutes for me to see any food at all. The person sitting next to me at the bar was quoted 50 minutes, and he sat there with no food until I was done eating.Then, to top it off, they took forever to give me the bill. I had to flag down three different waitresses before I could pay them. Then a week later, I realize that they charged me twice on my card. I'm going to drop by tomorrow or something to get it refunded - but how annoying!I was really excited to find a very highly rated sushi place a 5 minute walk from my place, but it was a disappointment.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom

r64aDm7416Q4mfDUvjWfnw.text: Food: Everything we ordered was really good. I would highly recommend the pork belly, fried aubergine with soya paste, and quail eggs. The sushi was also very fresh!Service: Not good. Our waitress was super friendly but the food took a long time and we had to ask for water and the bill multiple times.Ambiance: Quaint. It's small and charming. The vibe is pretty authentic.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly

mGYe2YvMuwvDxKnkQYEcmg.text: Julia D and I were lucky to get a couple of seats when we rocked up on 6:30 on a Friday night, I would recommend booking ahead when coming on Friday or Saturday as other attempts to come here haven't been too successful. Asakusa is a very popular spot!I ordered chicken katsu and miso soup. Julia D went for a range of different sushi which she was very please with. The staff were super helpful and kept filling up our water which is rare for London. The whole bill came to around £25 which was very reasonable considering the amount of food we had.

QmHP9GDLuLLAXP22FRUu_A.text: Will only be visiting here for sushi. Been on a search for good local spot sushi place in central London for a while and experienced so many places that has warm poor quality tasting sushi that just had to do the job of curbing that sushi craving. Japanese owned and staff are nice. Btw, beware of the 40 minute wait to get your sushi order.Must make a reservation!

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Red bean mochi dessert
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Tuna with soy bean sauce
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Steak

KyS8K9Ji-oblBszZRnmcrg.text: I got a recommendation to come here from a couple of people. I called and they didn't have any reservations, but I chanced it and decided to come see if they'd seat us. I came around 6:30 on a Friday night and they seated us at the counter immediately. The whole place was just lovely. I ordered tofu with bean sprouts, fried miso eggplant, shiitake mushroom sushi, and miso soup. Matt b went for chicken katsu. Everything was perfect. My fave dish was the miso eggplant. The staff was super nice and even refilled my water. I'll definitely be coming back as much as I can. The total price was reasonable, too. 27 pounds for dinner and drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Husband with decor
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. All the sushi
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Sushi chef

uX1TL01LA2GQBL4Ey-mfBw.text: Deserves less but don't have that option unfortunately. Was confused based on the reviews. Anyway the fish is definitely far from fresh. Has a very bad taste and smells bad. Even when you sit down you can smell something from the stairs oozing into your nostrils which makes a bad meal even more disgusting. The service is awful and when I say awful I'm saying a complete joke. You might as well have just made yourself or paid a ten year old to help. Everything is dirty and outdated, it's really beyond me why this place remains open. If you like your stomach stay away, if you like your toilet come check it out.

yVZfqspqUWlVMJEYQxz00g.text: SO you like Japanese food and want to have a taste of what a good isakaya is without travelling 13 hours to go to Japan???? Then you on the spot  .... Asakusa is the place to be.The menus are both in English and Japanese and the staff are able to speak both languages. The felling i can tell is that you are actually in Japan. Now on the subject that matters ... Food....... Simply said aweeeeeeesome. There is a variety of small dishes you can choose most of them very typical for a Isakaya restaurant along with the normal selection of Sushi. But if you want to follow my advice skip the sushi and eat all the rest. Additionally you can quince your thirst with real Japanese sake and beer. Skip the wine section as its not so great ( you are after all in a Japanese restaurant and Japan one thing they are not known for is wine)The only reasonthat i am giving them 4 starts instead of 5 (and believe i had to really contemplate on that) is the booking procedure they have. Although you might be lucky to find something if just walk in when you try to book on the phone they seem to be a bit rude whether you do it in Japanese or English. So i will keep visiting and hope they will fix that ... that 5 star review is just around the corner

_c-ldYl5aVocawq51d28Kg.text: Terrible service and terrible hot food. The only good thing we ordered here was a tuna avocado roll. The salmon sake sashimi was mediocre, but maybe the nigiri might have been better.Pork belly: ridiculously tough to eat and so salty. Terrible.Chicken meatball skewer: way too salty. I don't understand why they need to put so much salt on everything.Asakusa udon: just ok. Their definition of vegetables on the menu is seaweed only. The mochi was weird and eel did not taste so great. Only good thing were the soft chewy noodles.Salmon sake sashimi: ok. Tough to eat and I've definitely had better.Tuna avocado roll: this was the best thing ordered and was actually really good. Expensive and a huge disappointment. The male server has a terrible attitude problem. I'd highly recommend going elsewhere.

SIP2hcjx1IO16tZ6i6ho1A.text: I love Asakusa.I had a Japanese boyfriend in my first year of University (quite a long time ago- eep!) At that time I had only lived in Japan for about 6 months...and I was used to eating my host mother's amazing cooking...so after i moved to London, I really missed unpretentious, decent Japanese grub. Back then, Asakusa came to the rescue! It has always been cheap, but incredibly tasty. I also love that the menu is written all over the walls, so I could practice kanji while eating out - that sort of counts as studying!!Anyway... now I've yo-yoed between London and Kansai all of my adult life, if it always good to go back to the awesome places from my student years and find that they are still tasty, reasonably priced and just as dodgy-looking as ever!**I should probably mention that my Japanese boyfriend left me broken hearted yeeears ago, but Asakusa has never let me down...and even helped me seduce my lovely current man. *Starts to drool thinking of both...*

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Asakusa sushi joy (^^)

v1yWDT_lzRCDmp-bYQ0Cog.text: Asakusa is a tiny, hole in the wall that serves authentic Japanese food and is great value for money. I loved the salmon sashimi, as I always do, and I love the bustling and elbow to elbow little Japanese world in here. I tried nasu dengaku for the first time, and it was really nice! The genmaicha was also great and the maki rolls I had here were good. Asakusa is a place I will definitely come back to!

photos.caption: Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Salmon sashimi
Photo of Asakusa - London, United Kingdom. Nasu dengaku

-YDnxN17Lirki5dcLHKNWQ.text: Asakusa. It's been on my main list of places to visit for some time. I took a friend who was over from LA. Now, if you've been to LA you know that they get very good Asian food. Korea, Thai, Vietnamese and of course Japanese (esp raw fish). I took her there knowing that Asakusa was highly rated by locals. I was lucky enough to get a last minute booking very early in the evening. 6pm when it opened to be precise. It looks very lacklustre from outside. Bit old hat you might say. And inside it's no different really. But, and eventhough I have an eye for decor and design, when it comes to eating out, it's all about the food for me. Anything else is a bonus. I ordered for us, being the OCD person that I am, scanning reviews the night before and knowing what to get. The baked aubergine is sweet and large. Good to share. And best to have with a starch or protein as on it's own it would be too sickly. I had to get prawn tempura. Which was very fresh and light. A winner for me. The Karaage chicken was good, but not the best I've had in London. It was not oily at all. But that's where I was kinda disappointed as it almost looked too healthy. No glistening. It was a big portion of 4 pieces on the bone. But I do prefer my karaage (like Korean Fried Chicken) boneless. Onto the fish...the black cod is something I read to be a certainty to order and I really liked it. Sweet undertones on the the cod it was good. The horse mackerel was not in, but the server kindly explained there is not much difference! So mackerel nigiri it was. I love mackerel. One of my fav fishes and this was good. The spicy tuna rolls were more coarse than some you might find but this did not detract from the dish. Very good maki rolls.So all in all it was good. Not great but good. But this was my first visit and I'll be back for another try for sure. And the service was lovely and attentive. They even got me Japanese Mayo for my Karaage chicken when I asked for some. So good work. A solid 7/10.

TVoY-EX8FIz2azZOphUjbQ.text: You know what really frustrates me? When a restaurant with really tasty food has really horrible service. Why can't people get things right?There were five of us here, and we had a reservation, but we were seated downstairs. I mean it's nice that they have a downstairs room, but it smells awful getting to it (because of the toilets). I can't help but wonder if the terrible service had to do with us being seated downstairs, but whatever.We ordered a lot of food. And all of it was good. Sashimi? Delicious. Sushi? Tasty. Skewers of various types of chicken offal? Really amazing. Tonkatsu? Awesome. Tempura? Great. It just took forever. It's like the kitchen staff don't know how to organize themselves to cook things in a timely manner. Weird. You know what else took ages? Getting our saki. The first batch of saki we ordered? Took FOREVER to arrive. You know what else took ages? Getting a server's attention so we could order more saki. You know what took even longer? Getting the servers to refill our water when we repeatedly asked them to do it. We also tried to order a bit more sushi at the end. Like I've done at every other sushi restaurant I've ever been to anywhere ever. And it was going to take 30 minutes. Not cool guys, not cool.I guess when they know people will keep going to a restaurant because the food is good, they can be horrible servers. However, I think that a place with good food isn't worth going to if you have to deal with service like that. So I won't be returning even though the food was some of the best Japanese I've had in London.

-adlQAJ4j_Wua4ID9pezkw.text: This is a mixed review as the restaurant has a cool genuine izakaya feel to it and the food is quite good and reasonably priced, but the problem is the service is SO SLOW. I mean, you could literally die of hunger in this place.  The main issue is there is only one sushi chef in a tiny bar to make all of the cold dishes. Combine that with the fact he is probably the slowest sushi chef I have ever witnessed means like me you will probably still feel hungry after being in the restaurant for 2 hours!!!!!! Too bad given that the dishes that do come out are good! If you're there as a group and don't mind drinking between snacks then it's a winner but don't go unless you have a 2-3 hours to kill.

m88l7PVaEAG7m4VryHXM-Q.text: I had really high expectations for this place since a few friends recommended it and overall it was a good place to try but not sure if I would go back.We went on a Sat and it was packed so good thing we made a reservation. Surprisingly we started with udon noodles and chicken teriyaki, which is so weird because usually you end with that. Then the sushi and sashimi came after a very long wait and by that time we weren't so hungry after the hot food! :( The sushi was mediocre, the sashimi was a lot better but their was something wrong with the tuna as it was a bit stringy. I got the sesame ice cream to end. The staff were really friendly but you have to wait a while for the food. Not the best date place I have to say but happy I tried it.
